@sreenathkamath Due to the version bump, master is broken: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3260. Will be merged soon
@feng-tao Could you rebase onto master? Master has been fixed. Also, could you shorten the title of the commit (50 chars max)?
Totally agree.

@wileeam The new Kubernetes helm charts have an init-container for the worker, that will do a git clone of the remote repository (using git-sync). Currently I have two concerns:
- Security, this will run under the scheduler, and will have full access to the database. Also, from a auditing perspective, it is hard to track which code has been executed, since it hasn't been commited to version control.
- Compatibility with the different executors. This will only work for the {Local,Sequential}executor, since the Celery and Kubernetes have the Airflow dags distributed.

Maybe we can integrate git-hooks in Airflow. When the source repository gets updated, Airflow will get a notification and will do a git pull.
Ok, let's see how bad I am at writing tests blind (no CI locally :)

@rsubra13 it's in the 1.10 release, which is currently in beta
@gglanzani You can setup Travis CI on your fork for free as it is open source. If you setup to build your branch you can check your results there faster, as your build will be in its own queue.
@Fokko , actually let me add a test for this pr as well :)

@gglanzani that would be awesome! Donâ€™t know about the warehouse honestly, getting hive up and running in the container is pretty tough (no hdfs) so Iâ€™m not sure if it is entirely â€˜normalâ€™. On upgrading hive Iâ€™m a little in doubt. How widespread is the newer hive? It really takes a long time before everyone migrated. But given the fact our tests are not testing all of hive (and they should have to), I think it is fine to upgrade to a newer version. If you can get it up and running of course. Still in a separate PR please.
Ideally we split integration tests away from the unit tests. That should be faster overall. Quite an undertaking though.
Or have a gitlab ci version available.
@Fokko / @bolkedebruin can you guys commit this to 1.10 branch too as a hotfix? Thanks.
O we missed it. Sure we can.
Thanks!

@bolkedebruin everything should be good to go now

Yes, working fine!
@gglanzani nice one!!
@Tagar it was actually already part of 1.10.0beta1

@r39132 I can confirm this works on the same Safari version. You probably need to clear your browser cache first (Develop â†’ Empty Caches). I've tested it again, it's essentially a one-liner change so .. without the change: 

![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62379/39249096-c936d422-4895-11e8-8130-ba985bdb2209.png)

With the change:

![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62379/39249120-d5547548-4895-11e8-901f-c62d5d269cc1.png)  

I would argue this is an issue with Typeahead library, although the latest version (4.0.2) is the one Airflow uses. It's really a small annoyance, affecting only Safari and the workaround here seems to help.

@r39132 yeah this requires rebasing. Maybe I'll create a fresh PR. Will look into it this week.

Thanks for revisiting this PR.

that's great. thanks for confirming .
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2351 reads Fix Version = 2.0.0 only so I got confused.
@bodschut any updates on this PR about adding tests?

@Fokko see response from @andialbrecht 

> sqlparse aims to be a generic SQL parser. There is no official list of
> dialects. We've added some dialect specific features recently to improve
> parsing. But there are no plans to have a dialect switch. Keep in mind that
> sqlparse doesn't validate. sqlparse should also work in editing
> environments where the sql statements are invalid most of the time.

If played with Oracle parsing and it works for our DML and DDL statements.

Does it sound like a good plan to have this functionality based on `sqlparse` module?
Thx +1

@byang2013 Are you interested in taking this forward? If I don't hear back in a few days, I'll close this PR. @someword @jimsmith @msumit @andylockran if one of you would like to take this word forward in a new PR, please do so.

@v-sukt You do need to follow the [commit guidelines](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide), which are also repeated for the most part in the PR template / instructions above.

Also, please combine all 4 of your similar PRs into a single PR with a single Jira. Then prefix the commit with the Jira id (e.g. AIRFLOW-1212) and squash your commits. If you fail to do so, we will be closing your 4 PRs shortly.

@clintonboys You need to follow the [contribute guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide): This means, that you need to prefix your commit and PR with `[AIRFLOW-XXXX]`, where `XXXX` is the JIRA number. Hey, you should probably use a more descriptive PR name :)

^^ specifically, you need to have an open JIRA, reference the JIRA in the commit and the PR title.  And your PR should have all the "boilerplate" with the check-boxes etc.  If you do that you will probably get your PR through :) Hope it helps.
